content: Being an architect, I had a high-level view of all technical developments on the project. While that sounds cool, it has its disadvantages. The higher you go up the ladder, the less of a concrete impact you have on the game. You’re either a grunt who works on a tiny part of the game (“See that lamppost? I put it there!”), or you’re a high-level director who writes emails and goes to meetings (“See that road full of lampposts? I approved that.”). Both positions suck for different reasons. No matter what your job, you don’t make a significant contribution to the game. You’re a drop in a glass of water, and as soon as you realize that, your ownership evaporates in the sun. And without ownership, there’s no motivation.
